discussion.content:
C
The most accurate statement describing what these policies allow the organization to do is C: "Encrypt, decrypt, and rewrap data using the transit engine all in one policy."

choices.C: Encrypt decrypt, and rewrap data using the transit engine all in one policy
choices.D: Create a transit encryption key for encrypting, decrypting, and rewrapping encrypted data
choices.A: Separates permissions allowed on actions associated with the transit secret engine
choices.B: Nothing, as the minimum permissions to perform useful tasks are not present

questions.question_text: Your DevOps team would like to provision VMs in GCP via a CICD pipeline. They would like to integrate Vault to protect the credentials used by the tool. Which secrets engine would you recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Google Cloud Secrets Engine in Vault allows dynamic creation of short-lived GCP IAM credentials. This is ideal for provisioning VMs securely in a CI/CD pipeline because:

It avoids storing long-lived credentials in pipeline configs.
Credentials can be automatically revoked after use.
It integrates directly with GCP IAM to create temporary service account keys.

questions.question_text: Which of these is not a benefit of dynamic secrets?

choices.C: Ensures that administrators can see every password used
choices.A: Supports systems which do not natively provide a method of expiring credentials
choices.D: Replaces cumbersome password rotation tools and practices

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Dynamic secrets in Vault are generated on-demand and automatically expire, making them more secure. However, administrators do not have visibility into every password used, because Vault never stores or logs the generated secrets.

Selected Answer: B
Authentication Method allows you set it. Mount Endpoint Configuration too as per https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/api-docs/system/mounts#tune-mount-configuration and D & E clearly allow you define TTL for a token.

questions.question_text: Which of the following cannot define the maximum time-to-live (TTL) for a token?

choices.D: Orphan tokens do not expire when their own max TTL is reached
choices.B: Orphan tokens are not children of their parent; therefore, orphan tokens do not expire when their parent does
choices.A: Orphan tokens are tokens with a use limit so you can set the number of uses when you create them
choices.C: Orphan tokens are tokens with no policies attached
